item.title: Discrete Fourier Transform
item.description: Note This article assumes you have a basic understanding of Fourier Transforms. Sampling Shannon-Nyquist Theorem N sample > 2f or f < N/2 Matrix Multiplication

item.title: Fourier Transform
item.description: Imagine you are given a function $y = f(x)$. Now what if I asked you to to represent this function as a sum of sine waves? Seems tricky, if not impossible at first. It might look daunting from afar, but the underlying principle behind Fourier transforms is actually relatively simple and really elegant. Time v Frequency A time domain vs a frequency domain graph of the same signal Use Cases Sound Processing Euler’s Formula The complex plane for any number, $x^{yi}$ results in a comlex number $a + bi$.
